segments.text: And so we're running on, at the moment, we're running on a pretty constant year to year with not only the increases that would keep up to the consumer price index or something.
We are growing.
The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution has actually shrunk a slight amount in the last three years.
We haven't grown at all in terms of the number of people we have working here or in terms of the dollars we have when we put them into non-inflated terms.
In other words, that you're suffering from the process of inflation like everybody else.
I didn't say we were suffering.
I said we weren't growing.
It could be suffering.
I didn't say that, though.
You're assuming something there.
You're assuming that vigor is better and that to live is to grow.
And it may be true.
I'm not saying that.
That's a separate question.
I'm just saying that our funds have not grown.
in real terms, and the institution has slightly increased.
That may be good.
Maybe it's time to retrench a little bit occasionally.
Maybe the best thing that could happen for any kind of organization is to pause in a while, and then grow, and then pause, and then grow.
During the pause period, you were able to retrench and do things you may not do in the hectic periods of tumultuous growth.
Does it seem to you, as an insider, that the so-called glory days of oceanography may be ending in terms of funding?
I don't know what you mean by glory days, but I'll assume that you mean periods in which there were real increases in budget year after year.
No, it could easily happen again.
Oceanography is a pretty sexy subject, and if it's packaged right, it'll sell.
There are people who'd like to see it grow again, and I expect it will.
If there are people at Woods Hole who would like to participate in that growth, then I expect they will because we have good people here.
They're in a position to capitalize on any opportunities to get increased funds.
There seems to be a movement on the national level to place all of the oceanographic funds or all the oceanographic grading institutions under one central agency, probably in commerce.
Do you approve of that?
No, I don't think it's a good idea.
I think one of the strengths of the American system is its plurality, and that if we lose this, we lose the ability to correct mistakes.
And the price you pay for plurality is a slight amount of repetition or duplication.
I think in oceanography this hasn't been great.
And we get our funds from a host of different agencies and segments of the economy.
And what we can't do one way, we often are able to do another way.
And it's those things we do another way that often in the long run turn out to be the most important scientifically or intellectually.
And that's what really counts, not
And having a single agency would be bad for the country.
I don't think the United States needs a single anything.
We're a big country, and we can afford, in most cases, to keep a pluralistic society.
One of the things that impresses me about this country, as opposed to countries which have a centralized planning and economy, they suffer greatly from it.
Because if that central organization makes a mistake, you don't have very effective ways to redress, whereas we do.
And that makes us stronger.
There also seems to be a trend in oceanography since the Mansfield Amendment to go more to directed or practical research, as it's sometimes called, rather than theoretical research.
Is that your impression?
My impression is that, yes, there are those pressures.
There is a feeling, let's say, in Congress that they'd like to support science in general, not just oceanography that's more applied.
I think, though, if you look at most of oceanography over the years, a good percentage of it is what you might call applied research.
It's had goals that are fairly well understood, either by the people who are doing it or by the people who are funding it, or both.
Sometimes both sides didn't know what the objective was.
We looked at our budget here.
A few months ago, we were curious.
As this comment had come up, we went through what we had.
And I've forgotten the number.
We had something like 50% of our work in this institution could easily be called applied, we felt, just by looking at what was going on and what its objective would be.
And not in all cases would the people doing the work agree with that description of their character, of their work.
But we knew from other factors that there were things going on.
There were people waiting for the results that they may not have known about in a few cases.
OK. Sea Grant, was it a good idea or a bad idea?
It was a good idea.
It's got some problems.
Its major problem today is that it's, I think, is too narrowly construed in its perspective.
And it's a good idea in the sense that it complemented what we already had.

And in line with my comments I made a little while ago about pluralism, I think it's good to have another agency who is interested in marine or marine-related things that doesn't overlap with anything else.
And it gave us one more string to our bow.
And for that reason, I feel that Sea Grant is good, and I'd like to encourage its continued growth.
It needs to grow a little bit, though, because it is a little bit narrowly conceived at the moment.
There also seems to be a trend for more in-house research of government institutions.
I don't know that I agree with you about that.
There's a natural trend in any organization to keep things as close to your vest and do it in-house.
The federal agencies would like to do that.
The pendulum swings a little bit, and maybe the last few years have been belt-tightening, and they've done it.
But if you look at the, again, I looked at some numbers last year on this.
I was quoting some other numbers a moment ago.
Other numbers, I tried to get the amount of money used in-house federal laboratories for ocean research.
And I found over the same period that private laboratories hadn't grown, neither had that portion of the federal lab research program.
I think there's also an awareness and part of many congressmen

that it costs more money to maintain a civil servant to do research than the same amount of research costs outside universities because of the nature of the bureaucracy in the federal government and for other reasons.
And this is well known by many of our congressmen, and I think that if the pendulum swings too far in the way of in-house research, I think there will be probably strong steps taken to
spread it around and decentralize.
Again, as part of this pluralism, we have a federal system of laboratories.
We have a private system of laboratories.
We have university laboratories.
We have non-university laboratories.
It gives us ability to do things in a number of ways.
And I think there are forces that try to keep that pluralism in effect.
And certainly, it's a gut feeling of any guy running a federal lab to keep the money in house.
He's going to want to do that.
That's human nature.
But there are forces working against that, too.
Reviewing grant proposals, are you happy with the review system of grant proposals?
Generally, yes.
And you prefer, in effect, peer review?
I thought you meant peer review, yes.
I think the system generally has slight flaws, but generally I like it.
Yes, I think it's a good system.

I realize we were working here, though, on a system where we don't all, again, this pluralism, only about half our grants and contracts in this institution go through the peer review system, and the other half don't.
But I'd like to have that system.
I think keeping it and keeping it healthy is an important component of our overall way of doing research.
ONR doesn't use a peer review system.
IRDA doesn't use a peer review system.
15 or more percent of the money we have for research in this institution comes from non-federal sources, and that's philanthropy and foundations and things.
They don't use a peer review system.
But I think the peer review system is important, and I think it ought to be maintained.
I admire the NSF system of doing it.
I think, except I realize there are cases where it breaks down and somebody, because he has the right name or the wrong name, does or doesn't get funded and so forth like that.
And those little things do happen.
But overall, I think 90% of the time, it's a very effective system.
Very good.
Do you anticipate working for a federal foundation or a federal agency in the future?
If I did, I would have done it by now, I think.
I've had lots of job offers frequently.
I'm not opposed to doing it, but I've never found one where I felt it would be something I really would like doing.
But I have no answer to your question.
Would I think it should be part of my training?
Not necessarily.
I know a number of people who've gone and done it.

more effective because they know their way around washington but there's no more other ways of learning about management in effect on the job training then that's one of them okay i can read about it too okay well you can go to school you can go to harvard business school there's all kinds of ways no there's all kinds not serious all kinds of ways to learn to be a manager and i think it's good we have a mix i i
I don't know why I'm getting this lecture on pluralism this afternoon, but I think there is important.
I think if you get all your peas coming out of the same shell, all the same pod, you're in trouble.
You want to have a mix of people.
You want to have some people who spent time in Washington.
You want to have some people who maybe spent time overseas.
You want to have people who spent time in the Harvard Business School or something like that.
You want to have this mix.
I think it makes a stronger group.
The whole community of oceanographic management will be stronger if you have this mix.
You don't want them all the same.
All ex-Washington bureaucrats would be terrible.
All anything would be terrible.
It would be terrible, right.
I agree with that absolutely.
Next series of questions concern your reaction to environmentalism, since you work with Erda and other people.
What is your basic reaction to the environmental movement?
Well, I think our awareness of environmental problems has come along very late in our human habitation of the planet, and many of our concerns are quite serious.
The ocean is important.
has an important role in the environment and in maintaining the quality of the environment.
So it's important that oceanographers be heavily involved in the center of this discussion and this national debate, international debate.
There has been a tendency in some groups, even including some oceanographers, to overreact on problems.
On the other hand, there are people who I think are just crying wolf.
On the other hand, I don't believe that we should back off from environmental questions.
In fact, if we who work at the laboratories that have the means to get the data don't work on them, then all of society is going to suffer.
So I think it's important that we work on them.
I think it's important we work on them with as much scientific purity as we have.
We should be intellectually honest when we do so.
And I think most people I know are.
There are a few individuals who are exploiters or alarmists and the chicken littles, the sky is falling types.
And we find this in every walk of life in environmentalism.
A lot of the issues, a lot of the environmental issues, I think, are overdrawn.
Is it fair to say that as a scientist, when someone says such things as the ocean is dying or you disturb, do you feel as if it limits your role?
It depends on who says it.
And the person who says it is an oceanographer who has credibility.
It bothers me.
Nobody who said it yet, as far as I know, has the basis for saying that.
The ocean is not dying.
There are parts of the ocean which are badly poisoned.
The ocean isn't dying.
One or two species in it may be going extinct.
And I wouldn't underestimate that.
I wouldn't like to see the blue whale disappear.
On the other hand, I think we have to live in a world where we harvest protein.
And whales are part of the protein resource of the planet.
Many people would say we should never harvest a whale.
Don't understand the logic.
If we're going to eat protein, the whale, to me, is no more sacred than a cow.

and run the cattle on the grange you've got to use both of them effectively we've got to learn how to harvest whales we shouldn't this would be we're not using the planet effectively we don't harvest whales there's protein and oil and all kinds of things we need there and there are many crops there as far as i know there are many species of whales right now which are harvestable but
for technical reasons, which were unharvestable for political reasons.
I don't believe those political reasons are well-founded.
But I wouldn't like to see the great blue whale go extinct either.
I think that would be folly.
I don't see why we should do that.
I'd like to preserve our environment and the attractive features in it, but we're living here too, and man's a carnivore, and we've got to use the animals where they are, and whales are part of it.
There's an example of what I think of as emotionalism.
I think the whale issue is so tied up with emotion that we aren't talking straight about it.
Let me try to sum it up and see if I have it right on the tape, okay?
That you would agree essentially environmentalism is a good thing, but sometimes it's extremism
of its proposed body?
Well, I don't like the word environmentalism, because immediately that term is pejorative to me.
I think that as marine or as terrestrial scientists, oceanographers have a responsibility to look at environmental problems, problems that maintain the quality of the environment.
And many people I know are doing that and doing it responsibly and making solid, strong, positive contributions
enabling us to stop some of the abuses that are going on.
There are clearly many abuses going on.
We are poisoning, polluting, and all this kind of stuff.
We need to take action to stop that.
Action can be more effectively done on the basis of good information, which can be gotten by scientific research.
At the same time, I think the scientists also have a role in trying to stop some of the alarmists and publicity seekers who are doing this for their own ends.
And there are a number of those as well, I'm sorry to say.
And some of those have given environmentalism a bad name.

So I bet if you talk to a lot of American industrialists and talk about environmentalists, they'll start foaming at the mouth and talk about those commies that are trying to keep us from making a profit for ridiculous reasons.
And part of the reason they're foaming at the mouth
Some of the people associated with the environmental movement have been irresponsible and haven't looked at both sides of it.
We've got to get enough energy to keep our houses warm.
We've got to get enough food to eat.
Otherwise, we're committing suicide.
We've got to do those things.
The question is, how can we do it in the most effective way?
And some of the so-called environmentalists would have is just not harvest food and not get energy and kind of turn their back to things.
This is unrealistic.
When you say environmentalists, I don't know whether that's what you mean or whether you mean oceanographers who are studying the environment.
Well, I was thinking about the environmentalist movement itself, not really quite so much as oceanographers studying the environment.
Well, I'm a little concerned about the environmentalist movement because I think it's gone out of hand in many cases.
Now, in terms of oceanographers studying the environment, if I may ask questions there, what is the potential of the ocean, would you say?
And there was a time when it was sort of assumed that the ocean would offer unlimited potential for...
preserving and protecting man on Earth.
They talk about mariculture and...
Okay, I'm not an expert.
Let me interrupt you.
I'm not an expert on this.
There are people who've done quantitative studies on what the ocean will do for food.
The ocean will not do everything for food for man.
It'll do a small portion of mankind's total food needs.

maybe, or a significant portion, but not all, won't provide all our food, it won't provide all our energy, it won't provide anything, but it's part of the total contribution to man's food and energy and so forth, and that is, we don't know yet how to work it very effectively.
But it's now, some of the statements were made a decade or two ago about aquaculture and all the rest of it.
Many of them, when looked at quantitatively, turned out to have been exaggerations.
Now, the next series of questions are personal questions.
What probably surprised you the most in terms of technical innovations in your discipline of oceanography?
Anything occur that you didn't expect to occur?
What did you think was the most important technological development in your field during your career?
It's really a two-part question.
Were there any instruments developed which you didn't anticipate developing, which you think aided you?
And of the instruments developed, which did you think were the most important?
No, I don't find your question one that I can respond to.
OK. Every instrument I've seen, there have been somebody standing around and said, that instrument can't be built.
building instruments, for example, is an imagination combined with some good engineering.
We've had some good engineers here at Woods Hole who've built a number of instruments that people are using around the country now, around the world right now.
But I personally never was in a position where I thought, oh, that'll never, well, any given instrument, oh, that will never work.
And I was surprised where it just didn't happen that way.
Maybe if I had a mind that works slightly different, I might have thought that.
As for the kind of
I guess the second part of the question was, well, scientific advice or ideas?
What scientific advance helped you the most?
Probably technological advance rather than scientific advance.
Oh, well, certainly in my own career, these more current meters are what I worked with.
And it took a decade to get them to work right.
And now they're highly well.
They're 95%, 99%, 95% reliable right now.
And they helped me a lot.
I mean, that was my career.
In the last few years, it was a scientist who was based heavily on data collected from instruments like this.
And they were a completely new instrument.
I was involved heavily with trying to get the darn things to work.
Took several years of my life.
Were there any other technological advances you think in your period of oceanography that pushed the science forward?
Sort of quantum leaps.
In the period when I've been active, I can't today identify a quantum leap.
A quantum leap might be more easily identified with some perspective.
And if we look at the history of oceanography, we might find, for example, the whole last 10 years have been nothing but one big, huge quantum leap.
Certainly, we're doing things today we didn't do 10 years ago and the same as 10 years before that.
There's a whole host of instruments we think are standard today, CTDs, pardon the jargon, CTDs, so far floats, current meters.
All these are things that didn't exist 10 or 15 years ago.
They're all of which we take for granted today.

And maybe when the history of oceanography is written from the perspective of the year 2000 or something, we'll look back and say, my God, the years of the late 60s, early 70s were nothing but complete change over the field.
And maybe...

I've heard people say that the biggest change over in the field came about in the late 50s when oceanography went away from small sailing ships like the Atlantis into big ships like the chain where we could work anywhere in the world anytime, except in ice, let's say.
And that completely changed the nature of the program as we did.

Maybe when we get enough perspective and we're able to look back, we'll see if the biggest advance in oceanography came after the Second World War, 10 years or so after the end of the Second World War, in the mid to late 50s, when the U.S. finally was able to get large capability ocean-going vessels.
Maybe.
Theoretical advances in oceanography.
Were there any which simply took you aback in your fields?
Those that you were not expecting to curb?
Well, no, I don't think so, although I've listened to a number of seminars from theoretical people, and they come up with an idea, and I'm like, gee, that's really great.
I hadn't realized that would be like that.
But once I heard him explain it, I thought, oh, that's reasonable.
I don't know so much.
I came in just after the period when Henry Stommel did his most important works.
And it's clear looking now that his ideas
about the westward intensification of ocean currents changed all our idea, all our theoretical ideas about ocean circulation.
That happened in the decade just before I came into things.
I came into things in, I came into oceanography in 58, let's say, and Stommel did his, his important paper on westward intensification was written in 48.

So I came in 10 years after that, and by that time the, the fallout had been done, the damage had been done, and all kinds of people had rushed to get into the line and write papers cleaning up after him.
In general terms of oceanography now, I don't mean just in your particular discipline, were there any theories advanced which took you aback or seemed amazing?
C4 splitting, plate tectonics, all these things, of course, are already pretty well debated at the time you come into the field.
No, C4 spreading.
And C4 spreading is something that happened since I've been in the field, but it hadn't been my field.
And no, it didn't take me much back.
I was aware of the debates about continental drift, pro and con, back when I was a student.
I was aware of mantle convection because of work I'd done in geomagnetism, and when people said, oh, it looks like they're spreading at the center due to expression of crustal
convection and things like that, mantle convection, seemed reasonable to me.
I mean, I wouldn't have done it.
I'm not trying to claim any wisdom or anything.
It just didn't seem unreasonable to me.
Future career.
What next?
What do you intend to do?
Do you intend to stay as administrator, return to being an active oceanographer?
What new problems would you like to attack, if any?
I don't know what I'll do.
I haven't made up my mind.
It's not obvious that I will stay as an administrator.
I'd like to keep that option open, and I have the option, I think.
Although it's dangerous staying as an administrator because your brain cells atrophy.
The nature of research is to
quietly get deeply involved into something with a high degree of intellectual penetration.
The nature of administration is to give quick, rapid answers to questions on a variety of subjects so you get a superficial thing.
These two talents fight against each other.
And you've got to watch out when you're a scientist against the superficial answer.
And you don't do a good job that way.
So the longer you stay as administrator, the more you begin to take pride in giving a shoot from the hip on answers.
But that's not the way you do good science.
But I don't know what I'm going to do.
You don't have any clearly laid out plans for research?
No.
At the moment, I don't have any clearly laid out plans for research.
That's right.
There's a number of things going on that intrigue me.
For example, satellites.
My base is more in instruments.
Maybe there's a new instrument that might allow us to get data to make a whole new set of things.
a whole new set of ideas about the ocean.
My impression looking at them right now is we're not quite ready for it, so I'm a little hesitant about it.
But there's an example, maybe something like that.
If you were going to offer advice to a student again, personal advice to a student,
What particular discipline of oceanography would you suggest he choose?
Where do you think, in a cliche, where's the action going to be in the future?
I don't know.
If you ask me, I can't answer that question.
I don't think anybody knows.
I think anybody that says he does it is just posing.
I think that...
If you say where the job is going to be, I can tell you that right now there are more unemployed biological oceanographers and maybe geological oceanographers.
And I don't know of any competent unemployed physical oceanographer.
And most chemical oceanographers are well employed.
But who's going to make the next breakthrough?
I don't know.
You might answer that maybe the next big breakthrough is going to be in biological oceanography, because men have been kind of insomniac and disciplined.
discipline, and there hasn't been much out of it for quite a while.
It's the most difficult of all the branches, so it's so complex.

Maybe somebody will do something quantitative in biological oceanography and revolutionize everything, but on the other hand, it's a hell of a job, hell of a field to get a good job in, because there's too many people in it.
Okay.
Is there anything you'd like to add to the table?
No, it's, I can't think so.
It's hard to
If I had to replay the tape, I wouldn't give you the same answers twice.
Well, that means we won't replay the tape, huh?
No, of course not.
But it's interesting to have the opportunity for some self-reflection on some of these questions, introspection on some of these questions.
No, I can't think of anything else.
I can't think of any question I was dying to have you ask me, so I get it off my chest.
All right.
Well, that's good enough.
OK, good.
